text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service

This IRM revision is part of the Human Capital Office (HCO), Employment, Talent, and Security’s (ETS) continuing efforts to provide IRS Human Resource practitioners with the most current policies and procedures.
MATERIAL CHANGES
6.250.3.8.1 - Added clarifying information on annual internal report submission dates.

IRM 6.250.3.12 - Title changed to “Notice of Results and Touch Points.” Added additional verbiage clarifying “...regular mail or email.” In adherence to the 2010 Hiring Reform, notification will be sent at all four applicant communication touch points: application received, application assessed for qualifications, applicant referred or not referred to selecting official, and applicant selected or not selected for the job.
IRM 6.250.3.16.3, 45-Day Hiring Model Definitions; IRM 6.250.3.16.5, Reporting Requirements; and Exhibit 6.250.3 -1, Snapshot of Department of Treasury of 45-Day Hiring Model were deleted.

References to the impact of 2010 Hiring Reform on the certificate in IRM 6.250.3.13.1, Supplemental Certificates, and Exhibit 6.250.3-1, Guidelines for Rule of Three Process and Category Rating Procedures, have been deleted.
This IRM supersedes IRM 6.250.3, Delegated Examining Authority, dated November 10,
All Operating Divisions and Functions

, as amended by Pub. L. No.
of
, OPM established an Interagency Delegated Agreement, (TREAS-
Agreement) with the Department of the Treasury (Treasury). (
) The IRS is authorized by Treasury, through the TREAS-
Agreement, to examine applicants for agency positions or positions at another Federal TREAS-
agency. This IRM provides guidance for the establishment and operation of Delegated Examining Units (DEUs) within the IRS. (
) IRS DEUs are responsible for adhering to the “Agency Responsibilities” of the TREAS-
Agreement. A complete copy of the agreement can be obtained from the IRS/HCO website at: http://hco.web.irs.gov/recruitstaff/ externalhire/deu/index.html . (
) The IRS can examine applicants for all Title
competitive service positions all series and grade levels nationwide, except for Administrative Law Judge positions. (

) Any competitive examining for positions covered under the Luevano Decree will require a separate agreement between Treasury and OPM. IRS DEUs must use either an OPM-developed assessment instrument or their own assessment. (

) Positions covered under the Luevano Consent Decree are listed in the Delegated Examining Operations Handbook (DEOH), Appendix D available the OPM website at: www.opm.gov/deu. These positions must meet the following criteria: a. Be filled at the entry level (either GS-
or GS-
); b. Classified at a two-grade interval; and c. Have promotion potential to a GS-
or higher. (

) The IRS may only contract out for examinations that pertain specifically to vidual bureau occupations. a. Any tests for occupations found in more than one bureau, such as the TEA (Treasury Enforcement Agent) exam, do not fall in this category. b. The contract authority does not apply to federal governmentwide cation series, even though bureaus may be using bureau-specific titles. (
) OPM may review any competitive examining work performed by contractors ensure that merit system principles and standards are maintained as by
USC §

) The IRS must notify Treasury regarding the use of any contract for as it occurs (e.g., position(s) covered and contractor). a. Employment Offices (EOs) (within Human Capital Office (HCO), ment, Talent and Security (ETS)) will notify the HCO, ETS, Policy and Programs Office; and b. The HCO, ETS, Policy and Programs Office will notify Treasury. (

) Employment Operations may establish a new DEU by: a. Forwarding a memorandum requesting establishment of a delegated or examining unit to the HCO, ETS, Policy and Programs Office; b. Ensuring each member of the DEU is trained by OPM and the unit certified by OPM before starting operation; c. Ensuring test administrators are trained and certified by OPM before ministering any test (if applicable); d. Nominating a Test Control Officer (TCO) within the DEU if examinations will be conducted. The TCO must be certified as such OPM, and; e. Forwarding information that includes the unit’s point of contact, and address and phone numbers for the established DEU to the HCO, Policy and Programs Office. (

) Each year, DEUs must verify and report their unit contact information DEU ID number assigned by Treasury, point of contact, addresses and telephone numbers) to Treasury through the HCO, ETS, Policy and Office by September
th. (

) Employment Operations may abolish a DEU provided they have notified obtained all required clearances from within the ETS organization and a. Forwarded a memorandum requesting abolishment of a delegated examining unit to the HCO, ETS, Policy and Programs Office; (cid:
) The request must include the unit contact information and an explanation for such request. (cid:
) The request will be forwarded to OPM by Treasury for a final (
) HCO, ETS, EOs performing delegated examining must adhere to the guidance contained in the TREAS-
Agreement, OPM’s DEOH, and IRM a
, IRS Personnel Staffing Accountability. (
) HCO, ETS, EOs should maintain IRM

, along with the documents, as their Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) - along with SOPs and policies under which the delegated examining unit operates. documents should be readily available for oversight reviews performed by HCO, ETS, Policy and Programs Office, Treasury or by OPM. (
) HCO, ETS, EOs performing delegated examining are subject to an audit performed by the HCO, ETS, Policy and Programs Office, Treasury or by OPM. (

) If notified directly by OPM, HCO, ETS, EOs must notify the HCO, ETS, and Programs Office of any audits or return visits by OPM to conduct a follow-up review. HCO, ETS, EOs will provide a copy of OPM’s final findings to the HCO, ETS, Policy and Programs Office. (

) DEUs must maintain certification/recertification lists with dates of recertification for their members. Members must be certified and if for certified, timely recertified in order to continue executing delegated as a unit. The HCO, ETS, Policy and Programs Office will maintain the Units vicewide certification/recertification list.

Examining Authority
) OPM will provide recertification training to all DEU staff through an training process and schedule. (
) Recertification must occur every three years in order to maintain Examining authority. (

) The IRS must maintain an internal personnel accountability system to that delegated examining authorities are in compliance with law and merit Internal systems principles and that annual internal audits are conducted as stated Audit and TREAS-
Agreement. Report (
) The annual internal evaluation audit report meets the bureau’s personnel countability program requirements. (
) Discrepancies discovered and resolved as a result of the annual internal review must be documented and maintained for three years by the DEU. (

) Each DEU must complete a yearly internal evaluation audit report for sion to OPM through the HCO, ETS, Policy and Programs Office. The Internal ETS, Policy and Programs Office submits to Treasury all the annual Audit Report reports by the last Friday in June each year through
(e.g., June
, June
; June
). The report is standard, but may include tional reporting requirements based on new guidance from OPM or and IRS delegated examining. (
) An OPM-trained and certified Senior HR Specialist not associated with the delegated examining unit should conduct the annual internal evaluation and complete the report. (
) A copy of the internal evaluation report can be found on the IRS/HCO at: http://hco.web.irs.gov/recruitstaff/externalhire/index.html . (
) Each HCO, ETS, EO performing delegated examining must submit a report on examining activities to OPM’s Delegated Examining Information Report – System (DEIS). Examining (
) A copy of the quarterly report can be found in OPM’s DEOH on OPM’s System site at: www.opm.gov/deu . (
) DEUs must adhere to TREAS-
Agreement and conduct an annual evaluation audit requirements as stated in IRM
, Delegated of Delegated Authority, and IRM
, IRS Personnel Staffing Accountability, failure to comply could result in the revocation of authority to operate as a DEU. (
) OPM can revoke delegated examining authority if a review determines that DEU is not operating in compliance with the TREAS-
Agreement. (

) DEUs must post all job announcements using OPM’s governmentwide automated hiring system USAJOBS for a minimum open period of five Notice Period calendar days (providing the closing day does not fall on a non-work day) more to provide the public with adequate notice of the job announcement. (
) If an open period of fewer than five calendar days is prescribed, it must be clearly documented and justified in the examination case file (for

Discrepancies discovered and resolved as a result of the annual internal review must be documented and maintained for three years by the DEU.

DEUs must adhere to TREAS-1 Agreement and conduct an annual internal evaluation audit requirements as stated in IRM 6.250.3, Delegated Examining Authority, and IRM 6.10.1, IRS Personnel Staffing Accountability, failure to comply could result in the revocation of authority to operate as a DEU.
OPM can revoke delegated examining authority if a review determines that a DEU is not operating in compliance with the TREAS-1 Agreement.
DEUs must post all job announcements using OPM’s governmentwide automated hiring system USAJOBS for a minimum open period of five calendar days (providing the closing day does not fall on a non
work day) or more to provide the public with adequate notice of the job announcement.
If an open period of fewer than five calendar days is prescribed, it must be clearly documented and justified in the examination case file (for
6.250 Strategic Human Capital Management

purposes and third party review). The decision to have an open period of less than five calendar days can only be approved by the Employment Office Branch Chief and must be based on objective factors, such as the number type(s) of jobs expected to be filled, labor market conditions, and recent rience filling similar positions. In cases where the announcement is open for less than five calendar days, due diligence must be applied by the HR ist in reviewing any subsequent request for Superior Qualifications Appointment, Retention, and Recruitment incentives. The question that must be answered is, would the incentives have been required if the had been opened longer, allowing time for more applicants to apply?

) IRS offices have four basic options available for filling external vacancies petitively: a. OPM Examining Services can examine and issue a Certificate of through the use of a Servicewide interagency reimbursable agreement is administered by HCO, ETS; b. An OPM-certified IRS delegated examining unit can examine and Certificate of Eligible candidates; c. IRS can perform part of the examining activities through a DEU, or contract with OPM to perform other examining activities; and d. Offices can contract out the examining activities provided they meet criteria outlined in TREAS-
Agreement. (
) HCO, ETS, EOs must notify candidates of their rating and eligibility either regular mail or email. and (

Federal Hiring Reform, notifications are required to sent to applicants addressing the following four touch points: (cid:
) Application received; (cid:
) Application assessed for qualifications; (cid:
) Applicant referred or not referred to selecting official; and (cid:
) Applicant selected or not selected for the job. (
) In accordance with the OPM DEOH and the TREAS-

Agreement - Part DEUs are responsible for establishing a written procedure for processing of applicant’s request for reconsideration of his/her rating. An applicant through a non-automated or automated application system may challenge her rating, qualification determination, and eligibility determination by requesting a reconsideration in writing (or email). The reconsideration must include why the decision was incorrect and be based on information responses, in the case of an automated application system) provided at time of application. (

) The servicing HCO, ETS, EO will conduct the first level of review; the first reviewer ((HR Specialist, Senior HR Specialist, or Chief Employment) must a staff member other than the person who made the original decision. The designated first level reviewer will: a. Review the applicant’s responses to screen-out or ranking questions Caree
onnector resume submitted during the application process; b. Determine if an administrative error was made; c. Determine if the applicant is qualified for the position;

a. OPM Examining Services can examine and issue a Certificate of through the use of a Servicewide interagency reimbursable agreement is administered by HCO, ETS; b. An OPM-certified IRS delegated examining unit can examine and issue Certificate of Eligible candidates; c. IRS can perform part of the examining activities through a DEU, or contract with OPM to perform other examining activities; and d. Offices can contract out the examining activities provided they meet the criteria outlined in TREAS-
Agreement.

onnector resume submitted during the application process; Determine if an administrative error was made; Determine if the applicant is qualified for the position;

d. Determine if the applicant’s score or veterans’ preference needs to be adjusted; and e. If rating remains ineligible, respond in writing to the applicant within
business days, providing a detailed explanation of the reason for the decision. This must be accomplished without compromising the rating schedule or test materials, if applicable. (

) If the reconsideration results in a rating change, the applicant’s record reflect the new rating. The servicing HCO, ETS, EO will: a. Change the applicant’s status code/rating and give the applicant due sideration. A revised notice of results will also be issued to the No change will be made to the applicant’s responses to questions in ree
onnector (e.g., improper screen-out criteria used in template); and b. Track and document the reason for the change in Caree

onnector. certificate will be revised to reflect the new rating only if the certificate not been issued. Certificates already issued can be amended only if new rating is “ineligible;” the eligible applicant was improperly awarded higher type of veterans’ preference; or the rating error was made by rater/examining office. (
) In the event an applicant disagrees with the first level review, the applicant may request a second level appeal within
business days. A higher level staff member (Senior HR Specialist or Chief Employment) will be conduct the second level review (e.g., If the

st level review was conducted the Senior HR Specialist, then the second level reviewer would be the ment Section Chief or higher. If the first level review was conducted by the Employment Section Chief, then the second level reviewer would be the ployment Branch Chief or higher.) The second level review decision is final; there is no further appeal to OPM. (

) All correspondence relating to an applicant’s request for reconsideration, including the reconsideration decision(s), will be retained in the appropriate certificate case file. Refer to DEOH, Appendix C, for more information on records retention. (

) Applicants may change their responses to questions in an automated tion system or submit supplemental information only if the vacancy announcement is still open. Additional information submitted by the after the closing date of the announcement will not be considered. a. If an applicant updates his/her application to an announcement with dates identified and the eligibility changes or rating increases, the applicant will be considered with all other eligible applicants who from that date forward. Changes will not be retroactive. b. Ineligible applicants will only have their qualifications reviewed if a sideration request is received from the applicant. (
) An SF-
, Request for Certificate of Eligibles, or equivalent and certificate, must be returned by the expiration date unless the issuing office has autho- rized an extension. (

) When merging categories under the category rating process, selections be from within the highest quality category regardless of the number of dates as all candidates are equal. Internal Revenue Manual

d. Determine if the applicant’s score or veterans’ preference needs to be adjusted; and e. If rating remains ineligible, respond in writing to the applicant within
business days, providing a detailed explanation of the reason for the decision. This must be accomplished without compromising the rating schedule or test materials, if applicable.

Strategic Human Capital a. Preference eligibles receive absolute preference within each quality category. If a preference eligible is in the quality category, the selecting official may not select a non-preference eligible unless a request to over the preference eligible is submitted and approved in accordance
USC §

b. If two or less candidates (preference or non-preference) remain in the highest quality category, selections may be made from a merged consisting of the highest and second highest quality categories (
USC
]). A merged quality category will list all preference eligibles of non-preference eligibles. For additional information on the category rating process, please refer to the DEOH and IRM
, Alternative Rating and Selection c. However, if three or more candidates exist in the highest quality categories A and B cannot be merged. Refer to IRM
, Rating and Selection, for additional guidance on merging categories. (

) DEUs must determine and document the certificate with the appropriate code. The audit code should clearly define the action and/or reason for taken on each candidate listed on the certificate. The audit codes are listed the back of the SF
, “Request for Certificate of Eligibles.” A copy of this is located on the OPM web site at: http://www.opm.gov/forms/html/sf.asp. (
) DEUs must audit all certificates before a selectee(s) enter on duty. (
) Under Title
USC §

, agencies are required to keep appropriate related to delegated examining. HCO, ETS, EOs must maintain certificate Files files with sufficient documentation to allow for a complete reconstruction of examination process in the event of oversight review or an appeal or legal action. (
) Each certificate case file should, at a minimum, contain the information the DEOH Appendix C entitled “Records Retention and Disposition available on OPM’s web site at: www.opm.gov/deu. (
) Each certificate must be audited before the applicant enters on duty and the case file closed within
days of receiving the completed SF-

) As outlined in the TREAS-

Agreement, the DEU must ensure that the of any information to an applicant does not compromise the examination process or disclose confidential materials. The release of information must interfere with the merit systems principles, or intrude upon the privacy of others. Applicants may request and receive documents regarding their tion for a specific vacancy announcement under certain conditions outlined below, provided another applicant’s privacy and/or the examining process is not compromised. Under Title 5 USC § 1104, agencies are required to keep appropriate records related to delegated examining. HCO, ETS, EOs must maintain certificate case files with sufficient documentation to allow for a complete reconstruction of the examination process in the event of oversight review or an appeal or legal
Each certificate must be audited before the applicant enters on duty and the case file closed within 30 days of receiving the completed SF-39.

As outlined in the TREAS-1 Agreement, the DEU must ensure that the release of any information to an applicant does not compromise the examination process or disclose confidential materials. The release of information must not interfere with the merit systems principles, or intrude upon the privacy of others. ) The following material may be made available for review or photocopying by applicants when requested under the Privacy Act of

: a. Application material submitted by the requesting individual (notations made by raters or reviewers showing earned rating, veterans’ preference and final rating may remain as well as notations on experience blocks showing qualifying experience or quality level); b. Inventory register/cards or similar information provided by an automated process (information must be sanitized to include only the applicant’s mation to avoid an unauthorized disclosure of another applicant’s information and must receive written authorization from the requesting dividual), notice of results of examination or similar documentation; and c. DEU must maintain the information below in locked filing or secured (in the case of computer-based applications), to prevent unautho- rized access from a non-delegated examining person. a. Correspondence files directly related to the DE certification process pre-employment screening process and background investigations); and applications maintained in the delegated examining files. (

Agreement (e.g., Federal Labor Relations Authority [FLRA] decisions). , Employment (General). (

Strategic Human Capital (
) The IRS E
E Hiring Model requires an ongoing partnership between the HCO and Business Operating Divisions (BOD) to analyze recruitment (E
E) Hiring processes, integrate strategic hiring plans, and regularly monitor the status/ cycle time of vacancy announcements. (

) HCO is responsible for: a. Mapping the current hiring process, using OPM’s End-to-End Hiring Responsibilities Process from the time a manager identifies a need to hire until the selected starts their first day on the job. See http://www.opm.gov/wiki/ uploads/docs/Wiki/OPM/training/En
nd-Hirin
nitiative.pdf, page

b. Collaborating with selecting officials, managers, supervisors and HCO, ETS Division representatives to implement this policy; c. Evaluating recruitment processes/procedures/systems and streamlining standard operating procedures to ensure compliance with the E
E Model goals; and d. Satisfying labor relations issues/implications. (
) HCO, ETS, EOs will implement a

calendar day hiring cycle as required the governmentwide requirement to improve the Federal recruitment and Office (EO) process. HCO, ETS, EOs will ensure compliance with employment laws regulations and provide consistent hiring practices while implementing this policy. (
) HCO, ETS, EOs will use automated systems whenever possible to achieve shorter hiring cycle. (

) HCO, ETS, EOs, in partnership with the respective BOD managers and embedded Human Capital, should analyze the BOD’s workforce goals and develop strategies to respond to high attrition rates or unexpected staffing quirements (e.g., impact of new regulations). The analysis of current processes can identify problem areas and prompt the development of new streamlined approaches for recruiting. The analysis should identify recruitment strategies previously used to fill occupations that may assist in meeting future recruitment needs and meet or surpass the E
E hiring The HCO and the BODs will consider the various options provided in regulation to streamline hiring processes and to attract, recruit, and retain a highly competent workforce. (
) The IRS has a diverse mission that requires different and extensive tional requirements for employment (e.g., Criminal Investigator). Due to from E
E extensive requirements, it is necessary that certain occupations or specific Model positions are exempt from the E
E Hiring Model. Occupations and positions that are exempt from the E

E Hiring Model are: a. Positions which require extensive up-front assessments before a tional offer” can be made to an applicant (e.g., tests/other assessments scheduled by OPM or a vendor); b. Positions filled under internal merit promotion procedures; c. Temporary positions; d. Filing season and wave hiring positions such as in the Campus; and e. Senior Executive Service (SES) positions. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
S
6.250 Strategic Human Capital Management

HCO, ETS, EOs will implement a 80 calendar day hiring cycle as required by the governmentwide requirement to improve the Federal recruitment and hiring process. HCO, ETS, EOs will ensure compliance with employment laws and regulations and provide consistent hiring practices while implementing this

The IRS has a diverse mission that requires different and extensive occupa- tional requirements for employment (e.g., Criminal Investigator). Due to these extensive requirements, it is necessary that certain occupations or specific positions are exempt from the E
E Hiring Model. Occupations and positions that are exempt from the E
E Hiring Model are:

a. Positions which require extensive up

front assessments before a tional offer” can be made to an applicant (e.g., tests/other assessments scheduled by OPM or a vendor); b. Positions filled under internal merit promotion procedures; c. Temporary positions; d. Filing season and wave hiring positions such as in the Campus; and e. Senior Executive Service (SES) positions.

) The HCO will establish appropriate overall hiring timeline goals for that are exempt from the

calendar day standard such as those multiple assessments. The ETS Division will measure and evaluate its processes for these positions to identify opportunities for improvement. ETS Division will conduct ongoing discussions with managers and the Capital community at appropriate established venues (e.g., recruitment ences and employment conferences) to establish baselines and evaluating and measuring hiring processes for these positions.
